column1: FC Pakhtakor Tashkent (Uzbek: Paxtakor Toshkent futbol klubi) is an Uzbek professional football club
column2: based in the capital Tashkent. Pakhtakor literally means "cotton-grower" in English.

column1: Pakhtakor was the only Uzbek club to play in the top-level Soviet football league and was the only Central Asian club to appear in a Soviet Cup final. Playing in the Uzbek League since 1992
column2: the club has been the undisputed powerhouse in Uzbekistan since the fall of the Soviet Union
column4: including six in a row from 2002 to 2007. Pakhtakor also won seven consecutive domestic cups between 2001 and 2007
column5: winning eleven cups in total. Players for the club have won Uzbek footballer of the Year honours eight times
column6: and Pakhtakor teammates swept the top three spots in 2002. Club managers have been named Uzbek coach of the year twice.The team is also a perennial competitor in the AFC Champions League
column7: having reached the semi-finals of the competition twice in 2003 and 2004. Pakhtakor currently holds the record in number of consecutive participations in the AFC Champions League

column1: The word Pakhta (پخته) in Persian means cotton and "kor" (کار) is from verb  کاشتن
column4: kishtan (Tajik Persian pronunciation) ) which means "to cultivate"; so the combination "Pakhtakor" produces a job name and literally means cotton maker.

column1: Pakhtakor's first official match was on 8 April 1956
column2: and is considered to be the club's "birthday". Its first match was played against a team from the city of Perm
column4: presumably FC Zvezda Perm.  The first goal in Pakhtakor history was scored by Laziz Maksudov on a penalty shot and Maksudov's goal was the only and game-winning strike.The team was formed in three months
column5: and the government invited the senior trainer Valentin Bekhtenev from Moscow to recruit the best Tashkent players for the new Pakhtakor.  At the time
column6: the club was to represent Uzbekistan in Soviet football.In 1959
column7: the club was promoted to the Soviet Top League for the first time.  During the 1960s
column8: Pakhtakor's squad was anchored by the striker Gennadiy Krasnitskiy
column9: who led it to a 6th-place finish in 1962.  After periods back and forth between the Top League and the Soviet First League
column10: the club reached the final of the Soviet Cup competition in 1968 – the only Central Asian club to reach a Soviet Cup final – losing to Torpedo Moscow 1–0.In 1971
column11: Pakhtakor again departed into the First League
column12: but was not long detained in the lower division as it gained promotion the following year.Pakhtakor was the only Uzbek side to appear in the history of the USSR Championship during the Soviet era
column16: and 299 losses.  Their best league finish was 6th place

column2: Pakhtakor made it back to the Soviet Top League
column3: but shortly thereafter disaster struck the club and Soviet football.  During a flight to play Dinamo Minsk
column4: Pakhtakor's plane was involved in a mid-air collision over Dniprodzerzhynsk
column5: Ukrainian SSR. All 178 people aboard both planes involved died.Seventeen Pakhtakor players and staff members died in the crash:

column4: the club sponsors a youth tournament in memory of the lives lost in the disaster.Following the tragedy in 1979 and spurred on by its prolific goalscorer Andrei Yakubik a few years later
column5: Pakhtakor had its best record in 1982
column6: finishing sixth and in front of several Russian and Ukrainian football powerhouses such as Zenit Saint Petersburg
column8: and Shakhtar Donetsk amongst the few. Pakhtakor had a point deducted that season due to exceeding the allowed limit for the games tied (drawn)
column9: but it did not influence the club's final standings.

column1: After leading Pakhtakor to its best finish
column2: age finally caught up with Yakubik and he moved back to his hometown of Moscow to continue his football career. With the departure of their great forward
column3: the club struggled and spent six years in the Soviet First League.  Although the discontent of their fans grew
column4: Pakhtakor's reemergence as a major footballing force followed fast upon the dissolution of the Soviet Union.

column2: a new page began in the club's history. 1992 saw Pakhtakor participate in the first season of the Uzbek Oliy League. Since 1992 Pakhtakor have become the most successful Uzbek club with 10 Uzbek League titles
column3: and 11 Uzbek Cups. Until 2014 the club is the only team to have participated in all seasons of the AFC Champions League since its inauguration in 2002. Since 2002 the club participated 11 times in AFC Champions League.

column1: The participation in the AFC Champions League season 2011 was not successful. On 4 May 2011 in a match against Al-Nassr Pakhtakor lost and finished its Asian campaign. In that match
column3: Pakhtakor's coach Ravshan Khaydarov formed starting squad from youth team players and club made record in the AFC Champions League history as the youngest team of the tournament with average players age of 21
column4: 8. The average age of club players for season 2011 was 23
column5: 3. In 2014–15 seasons Pakhtakor won its 10th and 11th League champion titles.

column1: Since Bunyodkor's promotion to the Uzbek League matches between club and their other rival from capital
column3: considered by supporters of both sides and football journalists as Uzbek capital derby or Toshkent derby.

column1: The match between Pakhtakor and Neftchi Farg'ona is one of the most popular rivalries in Uzbek League held since 1992. The first match between the two clubs was played on 25 May 1992 in Tashkent.

Pakhtakor Markaziy Stadium was built in 1956 with capacity of 55.000 spectators. Stadium renovated in 1996. In July 2007 club management announced next renovation of stadium. Reconstruction works were finished in 2009
column2: the amount of capacity was reduced to 35.000 and stadium became all-seater stadium. In January 2010
column3: the stadium was chosen as best sporting facility 2009 of Uzbekistan.

column5: "Bojalar" and "Ummon" dedicated their songs to Pakhtakor Football Club.
